snippet: “Color Between the Lines” strives to document many of the forgotten abolitionist heroes of Brooklyn, with an emphasis on “many.”
abstract: Catherine Rampell reviews play Color Between the Lines at the Irondale Center, as part of the multisite project In Pursuit of Freedom. (M)
lead_paragraph: ''Color Between the Lines'' strives to document many of the forgotten abolitionist heroes of Brooklyn, with an emphasis on ''many.'' A series of short musical vignettes introduces, among others: James Pennington, an escaped slave who became a teacher; Henry Ward Beecher, the preacher at Plymouth Church; Lewis Tappan, the merchant and missionary who worked to free the Africans aboard the Amistad; and James Hamlet and Pinky, two slaves whose freedom was bought at fund-raisers in Brooklyn.

headline.main: Catalog of Brooklyn Heroes, Helping Some to Freedom
